In spite of his success and affluence Hollerith remained ‘aman of principle. He felt the Census Bureau’s Director was behaving unjustly when he ordered alterations made to machines Hollerith had designed especially for tabu- lating agricultural data during the 1900 census, The 20 special machines had been sold to the Bureau rather than rented. Hollerith felt so strongly that he brought suit against the United States Government—but he lost the case. Thus, at the age of 50, though eminently successful, he was still having to cope with the hurt of defeat and the sting of adverse testimony from his “friends,”

‘The following year, 1911, the internationally known entrepreneur Charles Flint, who had formed many busi- ness empires, took an interest in Hollerith’s business. He formed from three companies—the Tabulating Ma- chine Company, the Computing Scale Company of America, and the Bundy Manufacturing Company—the company called the Computer-Tabulating-Recording Company. An interesting note in the record of the merger *# js that Hollerith’s manufacture and sale of ecards amounted to one million cards per day and held promise of earning increasing revenue! Hollerith was paid §2 million for his share of his company and given a ten-year consulting contract at $25,000 per year to insure that he would not start a competitive company. CTR did not thrive during the first several years; in 1915 it hired Thomas J, Watson, Sr. as presi- dent and general manager. Acomplishments of Watson and the ultimate rise of IBM (which was formed from CTR in 1924) are legend now, Hollerith continued to invent and to produce patents during the years 1911-21, but he and Thomas Watson were not friendly. Hollerith’s assistant, Otto Braitmayer, who had begun work before

the tum of the century as Hollerith’s office boy, gained favor over Hollerith, Eventually Braitmayer became executive vice-president of IBM. C’TR’s and later IBM’s strongest competition came from James Powers’ business activities, IBM and Remington-Rand (which merged with Powers’ company in 1927) have been number one and number two in the data-processing field ever since.

© Hollerith’s Retirement Years

‘Tho things Hollerith most enjoyed were raising a fam- ily, gourmet eating, building houses, raising cattle, buying automobiles, and giving gifts to friends and neighbors. When he was young, Hollerith said that if he were ever wealthy he would have a wine cellar and a yacht. After 1911 he was wealthy and did buy a yacht. He also at- tained the wine cellar but was forbidden to drink be- cause ho had high blood pressure. He indulged in auto- mobiles; he owned one of the first electric automobiles in 1896; in 1905, a Waltham Orient; sometimes he owned many gimultancously. In 1908 the family moved to a 10-acre estate in Rockville, Maryland, and later to a 230-acre farm in ‘Tidewater, Virginia, where Hollerith raised Guernsey cattle and, among other public-spirited activities, gave bull calves to neighbors to help them improve their stock, Hollerith delighted in producing butter, hams, and asparagus and in getting oysters and shad from the Mobjack Bay on which the farm was situated, He repeatedly sent these items to friends as gifts. He bought electrie appliances such as clocks, washers, ironers, refrigerators, and vacuum cleaners as soon as they came onto the market and improvised a private source of electric power for them, He owned numerous boats but gave up his yacht in the Chesapeake Bay, with its five Norwegian crewmen, when World ‘War I prevented him from taking an ocean voyage which he had planned, Work on his Georgetown house, situated on three acres and still the home of two of his daughters, was completed in 1915. It has beon said that if Hollerith had invested $1 million in stock of CTR in 1914, and left it there, the stock would now be worth $2 billion. Hollerith died at the time of the stock market, crash in 1929 with no knowledge or regrets of such lost, oppor~ tunity, Still his own man, he ended his nearly three score and ten years in luxurious retirement, surrounded by a loving family. To the last he detested rules of spelling to the extent that this renowned statistician spelled the word “statistician” any way he pleased.
